reviewText: Every now and then, a classic character is born.  Enter Fivel.  In Russia, Fivel's family is threatened by cats, so they go on a boat that's bound for America--where there are no cats.  The truth is that America has as many cats as Russia did.  Fivel gets seperated from his family, who believe that he died.  Fivel spends the rest of the movie making new friends in America (including a cat). The first time I saw this movie, I fell in love with it.  This is a truly family classic.Fivel Goes West is one of those rare sequels that's just as good as the first movie--if not better.  Fivel and his family head west for a simpler life.  But there are cats in the west too.

reviewText: I saw the first film in theatres as a kid, watched the second on video and watched the tv show as well. The American Tail franchise is one of the better non Disney animated works which of course means it came from Don Bluth. I purchased this for my daughter on the strength of my fond memories and she was not disapoointed. I am by no mean taking away from the current generation for animated storytelling but the 80's and 90's were like a renaissance and this was part of the opening salvo of hits.I have also purchase Rock-a-Doodle/Pebble and the Peguin double feature and she loved those too.

reviewText: American Tale is a classic.  My kids were not born when it first came out.  I have always heard the song "Somewhere Out There."  but not seen the movie until now.  It is heart-warming and at the same time educational, showing the immigrant experience, with opportunities to explain how people came to America to seek new lives, and how they can collectively stand up to oppressors.My kids enjoyed it thoroughly as well as the sequel "Fievel Goes West", which parallels the American experience of moving westward.  Yes, there are cats (problems) out there too.

reviewText: In 1986, Steven Spielberg and Don Bluth brought David K.'s An American Tail to the silver screen. It's a classic. An American Tail was followed by an incredible sequel. I really like that-SPOILER!!!-Fievel's sister Tanya loves Fievel, compared to most sibling relationships, where siblings hate each other, and never gives up hope that Fievel is alive. SPOILER OVER!!! Both films feature top-notch animation and at least one film has an Academy Award winning actor who had actually won an Oscar by the time the film was made. I highly recommend both films. Both films also boast beautiful scores by James Horner and three excellent songs in the first movie and two good songs in the second movie.My only complaint is that both films are presented in the full-screen format rather than the original widescreen format.Rated G.

Title: N/A

reviewText: "American Tail" is one of my favorite movies from my childhood. I actually like "Fievel Goes West" better. I think it's probably just because I saw it first for some reason, though it also has better music. Although, Tiger becoming a dog always cracked me up too! These movies are definitely classics.*SPOILER ALERT* My only problem with these movies - the reason I cannot give them 5 stars - is because they pretty much both have the exact same plot. Fievel gets lost - in the first during the voyage to America and in the second during the train ride out west. (They are seeking a better life because they did not learn the grass is not greener on the other side in the first.) He manages to reunite with his family against all odds. In both movies, a fake mouse - either a rat dressed up as a mouse or a mouse puppet - befriend all the mice. This is the cats' doing, to trick the mice and catch them all. Only Fievel knows and has to save everyone. Actually, if you watch through movies 3 and 4, "Treasure of Manhattan Island" and "Mystery of the Night Monster," you'll get the same plot again! I forget which one, but there is a dog so small she is able to disguise herself as a mouse. Not bad movies though. In one of those, I forget which again, we move on from "America, the land of opportunity" theme to the evils of Capitalism. Relevant to today. *END OF SPOILER*Overall, very good movies. Also movies you can learn from. If you are bad at history, someone will have to explain it to you though. The movie was sad, but also light. I didn't really get a good sense of what they were running away from.
Title: N/A

reviewText: one of the nice things about having kids is taking them to the movies. and these two films, an american tail and feivel goes west were definite favorites. we had these two movies on vhs and wore them out. my kids are all teenagers now and probably not as interested in watching these kinds of films as they once were, but i really liked these two films a lot so i kind of bought them for myself! if you have seen them then you know how good they are. if not and you are searching for something good for your kids to watch, then i highly recommend. the story is about the experince of the immagrant coming to america, family and friendship, and the determination to persevere. the story and animation is top notch, on par with disney. many of the characters are voiced by popular actors, john cleese and dom deluise to name a few. this dvd contains both movies on one disc and even though it would have been nice to see them get the royal treatment that disney lavishes on their films, im still glad to have them. these are five star animated classics that your children will love and if youre a big kid then you'll love them too!

reviewText: For years I've remembered random scenes from this movie, but since the demise of VHS players I haven't been able to play the entire movie and piece it all together. Once I put the DVD in, though, it all came back.This movie is great, even for an adult. It's a nice blend of comedy, adventure, and suspense (okay, maybe not thriller-level suspense but still). Every character is lovable and the story moves quickly.Second only to 101 Dalmatians in this genre.

reviewText: One of The Best Animated Classics of All Time, American Tail Follows The Adventures of Fivel Mouskruitz, A Young Mouse Who Has Been Seperated From His Family on A Trip To America and Must Find A Way To Find His Family. Along The way, Fivel Befriends A Cat Named Tiger and Must Avoid Any Evil Villians on The Journey.Like All of Don Bluth's Animated Films (Such asThe Secret of NIMH,Rock-A-Doodle, andAll Dogs Go to Heaven) This is an Absolute Classic For Kids and Adults Alike. The Animation and Cast in The Film are Absolutly Brilliant and Amazing To Lookm At and Listen To. American Tail is The Second Best Don Bluth Film and is Great For The Whole Family.In The Film's Sequel, Fivel Goes West, Fivel Gets Lost Yet Agian on The Way To The West and Figueres Out An Evil Cat's Plan To Get Rid of All The Mice in A Huge Mouse Trap. After The Mice Don't Belive Fivel, He Decides To Save The West Side-By-Side With Westren Hero Wilie Burp and Best Friend Tiger.Unlike Most Don Bluth-less Sequels (Such asThe Secret of NIMH 2 - Timmy to the Rescue,All Dogs Go To Heaven 2, andAn American Tail - The Mystery of the Night Monster) This Was Great. John Clesse (Known as Fiona's Father inShrek 2 with Bonus Holiday Dvd - Full Screenand Nearly Headless Nick inHarry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Full-Screen Edition)) Was Great as the Evil Kitty-Cat With A Bit of A Soft Side. Dom DeLuise is Yet Agian Funny as The Cat Friend Tiger Who's The Main Comic Releaf Through The Film When He Learns How To Be A Dog.SPIECIAL FEATURES INCLUDE:-Sing-Along-Songs-Couting With Digit-Fivel and Tiger's Duo Dance-Rewase The Secwet Weapon-Wild Wild West RoundupThe Spiecial Features are Really Nothing Spiecial Mostly Made For Very Yong Fans and Viewers of The Film. But The Sing-Alongs are The Best of The Features on The DVD, and Worth Having To Learn all The Lyrics From The Films.Overall Ratings:An American Tail-5/5Fivel Goes West-5/5DVD-4.5/5

reviewText: It is easy to find reviews on the movie - which I think is fabulous - so I'll stick to relevant stuff:Obviously by today's standards, the cartoon images can't compare to pixar or just about any animated television show - if you can get past that to the story - it is impossible not to love this one! I remember watching it repeatedly as a child, and I wanted to share that with my son. At this price, I couldn't resist.I give the movie 5 stars, my only gripe is the packaging. I did a double take before opening it as it seemed to look like something that fell off the back of a truck (as in a knock-off). The plastic case is cheap and lightweight, the DVD itself looks like a copy - with the first movie on one side, the second on the other. The first movie on my DVD was on the side the second movie should have been on. No big deal, I flipped it over and it was fine - but I gave the product 4 stars because it doesn't seem like an authorized copy.However, it works fine and my son loves it, so if you are a fan and aren't looking for fancy packaging and lots of bells/whistles - go ahead and buy!

reviewText: Both of these movies were adorable and both had great picture and sound quality.  I didn't have any issues with them playing, discs didn't skip or anything.  The double feature has "An American Tail", and "An America Tail: Fievel goes West".  Both are rated G so there's not any "adults would only understand this joke" or "foul language that there's so they can cuss but act like their talking about something else" (see Shrek). I consider them both suitable for children but there are 2 themes parents should be aware of.  The first one is about Fievel being seperated from his family, which is really sad and scary to watch. There is also the theme that they're mice, which means cats try and eat them occassionally.  I didn't find either of these things all that scary as a child but if your child is at a young enough age (like under 6), these might be a little too scary at times for them.

reviewerName: Ohh Mama "I'm trying to help you."
reviewText: I enjoyed this double feature. I'd actually never seen the second one, "Fivel Goes West" .. but it was enjoyable. I am currently learning spanish-- and strangely.. I do remember all of the songs and most of the script from my childhood in English. This is a great way to make that transition to another language.The Spanish dubbing on for "Fivel Goes West" is poor. The songs are in English regardless. I also noticed that the translations are not direct on either version.. but I suppose thats where the phrase "lost in translation" comes in.As for the storyline... Very enjoyable. Very real for the time. It covers issues like-- immigrants being forced to "Americanize" their names to enter the country and fit in in a way that is undedrstandable for children. At the same time, a lot is open for discussion. Its got the "moral lesson" most parents want their kids to gain from shows... Great family movie. If you haven't seen it yet... shame on you. Get it for your kids.
summary: One of my favorite childhood movies... now on dvd with multiple languages

reviewText: This is a fun movie I bought because I used to watch it when I was little. The songs are really cute and catchy, and my daughter sings them all the time now. If you haven't seen it and are thinking about getting it for kids, just be aware that there are some scary parts in it. I didn't think so (or remember any from when I was young) until I showed it to my 5-year old niece, who started crying at one part, and my 2-year old daughter who was scared in it, as well. You never notice those things until you have kids!!
